title: Combinational Synthetic Approaches for Isoreticular and Polymorphic Metal–Organic Frameworks with Tuned Pore Geometries and Surface Properties
abstract: Isoreticular and polymorphic 3-D MOFs were prepared via the combination of direct solvothermal reactions, postsynthetic ligand exchanges of the MOFs prepared via the direct solvothermal reactions, and postsynthetic ligand insertions into a 2-D MOF. The appropriate pore dimensions, surface areas, and adsorption enthalpies of the MOFs combined well to produce the largest working CO
capture capacities via the pressure swing adsorption process.
text: Porous metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are very interesting materials because of their large surface areas and the tunability of the surface properties.
The pore geometries and surface properties of the MOFs can be utilized in various applications, including gas storage and separation.

The conventional approach for the preparation of MOFs is a one-pot solvothermal reaction with appropriate building blocks. However, the tuning of the pore geometry with desired surface property via a direct one-pot solvothermal reaction is a challenging task. Postsynthetic modification of MOFs is an alternative approach to obtaining MOFs with a tuned pore property.

Postsynthetic covalent modification of the organic linker of the MOF or postsynthetic dative modification on the framework metal center can be utilized for the modulation of pore geometry and surface property. Postsynthetic exchanges of the framework metal ions
in MOFs have also been reported as new approaches for the tuning of pore properties.
Recent investigations on MOFs are focused on CO
capture processes require various pore characteristics of the MOFs, depending on the specific process conditions.
The presence of a strong adsorption site in the MOF is very important for CO
capture in vacuum swing adsorption (VSA) and temperature swing adsorption (TSA) processes of real flue gases with typical ∼15% CO
The large adsorption enthalpy of the MOFs with strong adsorption sites such as open metal sites
is one of the most important factors determining the working CO

capture capacities in these processes. However, for the pressure swing adsorption (PSA) process between the pressurized real flue gas of ∼6 bar and the depressurized gas of ∼1 bar, a moderate adsorption enthalpy of MOFs with tuned pore geometry and surface property is more important in determining the working CO
capture capacities than a large surface area and/or large adsorption enthalpy.

Here, we report the preparation and characterization of a series of isoreticular and polymorphic MOFs with tuned pore geometries and surface properties via combinational synthetic approaches, direct one-pot solvothermal reaction, and subsequent postsynthetic ligand exchange (PLE) and postsynthetic ligand insertion (PLI) of the MOF prepared via the direct one-pot solvothermal reaction. The pore properties, including the pore dimensions and geometries and the specific surface areas of a series of MOFs prepared via the combinational synthetic approaches, were investigated. The potentials of the MOFs as postcombustion CO
capture materials based on the working CO
capture capacities in VSA and PSA processes are discussed.

All reagents were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification. Elemental analysis (EA) (C, H, and N) was performed at the Central Research Facilities of the Ulsan National Institute of Science & Technology (Ulsan, Korea). Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded as KBr pellets with a NICOLET iS 10 FT-IR spectrophotometer (4000–400 cm

). Nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectra were obtained on a Varian-600 NMR spectrometer. Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) data were recorded using a TA Instruments Q-600 series thermal gravimetric analyzer under flowing nitrogen gas. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were recorded using a Bruker D2 Phaser automated diffractometer at room temperature, with a step size of 2θ = 0.02°. Simulated PXRD patterns were calculated using the Material Studio software package
employing a structural model from single-crystal data.

A series of isoreticular and polymorphic 3-D MOFs could be prepared via the combination of (a) direct solvothermal reaction using Ni(II) ion and H
BTC as building components for the 2-D sheet of an
topology and bipy or pz as a pillar between the sheets and (b) PLE of, and PLI into, the MOF prepared via the direct solvothermal reaction. The microporous 3-D MOF, HB-d, of a 3,5-c

topology could be prepared via a one-pot solvothermal reaction. However, a similar solvothermal reaction in the presence of pz only produced another microporous 3-D MOF, GP-d, of the same 3,5-connection but different net topology,

topology. HP-e could only be obtained via the PLE. Similarly, GB-e or GB-i, which is isoreticular to GP-d, could be obtained via either the PLE or the PLI. The series of isoreticular and/or polymorphic MOFs are microporous and show interesting CO
sorption behaviors. Although the BET surface areas of the MOFs are not so large, the MOFs do not contain any open metal sites, and the adsorption enthalpies are not very high, the PSA working CO
capture capacities of HB-d and HP-e are the largest among the reported MOFs. The appropriate pore dimension, surface area, and adsorption enthalpy could work better for the larger working CO
capture capacity via the PSA process. The balance between the high adsorption enthalpy and the large surface area might be important for the high PSA CO
capture capacity. This work demonstrates the utility of the combinational synthetic approaches for the tuning of the pore geometry with desired surface property.

A review.  MOFs have versatile structures, high surface areas and high pore vols. - they can be regarded as good candidate materials for H storage.  There are many MOFs that have high H adsorption capacities at low temps., typically at 77 or 87 K.  The highest H storage capacity reported so far is 99.5 mg/g at 77K and 56 bar for NU-100.  However, the high H capacities of MOFs at cryogenic temps. decrease as the temp. increases to room temp.  This is because the H adsorption in MOFs is weak physisorption and the interaction energies between the H mols. and frameworks are low.  To develop MOFs as H storage materials that meet the U.S.DOE targets for an on-board hydrogen system, a serious challenge is still present in the design and synthesis of the MOF materials.  We may expect that highly stable MOFs having a large surface area and pore vol., together with many open metal sites and embedded catalysts for hydrogen spillover, would provide some pos. results for H storage at ambient temp.

We also discuss the current understanding of the methane storage mechanism in these fascinating materials and outline the future directions in this field. © 2010 The Japan Chem. Rational design microporous pillared-layer frameworks: syntheses, structures and gas sorption properties
Gao, Chaoying; Liu, Shuxia; Xie, Linhua; Sun, Jiangang; Ren, Yuanhang; Feng, Dan; Su, Zhongming

The solvothermal reactions of nickel nitrate hexahydrate, arom. carboxylic acids, and either 4,4'-bipyridine (bipy) or pyrazine (pyz) produced three open-framework compds., namely, Ni(HBTC)(pyz)·3DMF (2) (BTC = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate), Ni2(BTEC)(bipy)3·3DMF (3) (BTEC = 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylate), together with previously reported Ni(HBTC)(bipy)·3DMF (1).  Compd. 2 is the product when pyz pillars replace bipy pillars in the reaction of 1, and it is a 3-dimensional porous network where honeycomb grid layers constructed by Ni-BTC groups are interlinked by pyz pillars.  When the BTEC ligand takes the place of BTC ligand in the system, compd. 3 was obtained and it is a 3-dimensional connectivity with 1-dimensional channels where Ni-BTEC chains are interlinked by bipy ligands.  The three compds. feature permanent porosity, which was confirmed by N2 adsorption isotherm measurement, and the architectural features of 1-3 can be ascribed to pillared-layer motifs.  Also, hydrogen adsorption measured at 77 K for 1 shows an excess uptake of 3.03% at 20 bar.  Details of the synthesis conditions, crystal structures and property measurements of each new compd. are described.
Unfortunately, the quality of the HP-d crystals obtained via the reported procedure was not good enough for single-crystal structure analysis.

Curvature and parametric sensitivity in models for adsorption in micropores

The sensitivity of thε calcd. micropore size of zeolite Y in a fluidized cracking catalyst, based on empirical models of Ar adsorption, is tested by examg. the effect of curvature and by systematically verifying the magnitude of phys. consts. in the model equations.  The slit model provides a pore size of 0.45 nm, while the new cylindrical models provide values of 0.69 and 0.74 nm.  The latter values are in agreement with the known aperture size of zeolite Y, 0.74 nm.  By sep. varying the magnitudes of 5 of the phys. consts. in the model over a ranges of ±30%, it is concluded that the diam. of the oxide ion at the surface has a large effect on the calcd. pore size, while the other parameters have only moderate to small effects.  Preliminary application of the cylindrical-pore model to the isotherms of Ar on other zeolites and mol. sieves leads to promising results, esp. for medium-to-large-pore zeolites.  The cylindrical-pore model is a useful means for the transformation of Ar-adsorption data on a zeolite into a micropore-size distribution.
Enhanced carbon dioxide capture upon incorporation of N,N'-dimethylethylenediamine in the metal-organic framework CuBTTri
McDonald, Thomas M.; D'Alessandro, Deanna M.; Krishna, Rajamani; Long, Jeffrey R.

High capacity, high selectivity, and low-cost regeneration conditions are the most important criteria by which new adsorbents for post-combustion CO2 capture will be judged.  The incorporation of N,N'-dimethylethylenediamine (mmen) into H3(Cu4Cl)3(BTTri)8 (CuBTTri; H3BTTri = 1,3,5-tri(1H-1,2,3-triazol-4-yl)benzene), a H2O-stable, triazolate-bridged framework, is shown to drastically enhance CO2 adsorption, resulting in one of the best performing metal-org. frameworks for CO2 sepn. reported to date.  High porosity was maintained despite stoichiometric attachment of mmen to the open metal sites of the framework, resulting in a BET surface area of 870 m2 g-1.  At 25° under a 0.15 bar CO2/0.75 bar N2 mixt., mmen-CuBTTri adsorbs 2.38 mmol CO2 g-1 (9.5%) with a selectivity of 327, as detd. using Ideal Adsorbed Soln. Theory (IAST).  The high capacity and selectivity are consequences of the exceptionally large isosteric heat of CO2 adsorption, calcd. to be -96 kJ mol-1 at zero coverage.  IR spectra support chemisorption between amines and CO2 as one of the primary mechanisms of uptake.  Despite the large initial heat of adsorption, the CO2 uptake was fully reversible and the framework could be easily regenerated at 60°, enabling a cycling time of just 27 min with no loss of capacity over 72 adsorption/desorption cycles.
